poem:
### Desert Rains

In Yemen's parched embrace,  
storms uncloak secrets,  
tropical whispers unweave the sky.

Clouds rally forces,  
a low pressure symphony rising,  
thunder tales spun till Wednesday.

In Al Hudaydah, 50mm fall like  
forgotten prayers, grace descending,   
awakening bones of ancient wadi.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Weather tracker: southern Arabian peninsula braced for storms Unusual levels of rainfall are due to hit the southern Arabian peninsula this week, as a tropical wave – an elongated area of low pressure – progresses across the region, triggering a marked increase in convective activity across western Yemen and south-western Saudi Arabia this week. There is a risk of thunderstorms until Wednesday, with forecast rainfall totals reaching about 50mm for Al Hudaydah region in Yemen". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
